review_title: Just starting out my TA and am having a bad feeling
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Waterloo, ON
pros:
- TA funding is abundant and the amount almost covers the tuition.
- The faculty and the department that I am in are well-known across Canada and the world, which means rich academic resources and career opportunities in the future.
- Support from all levels seems to be comprehensive so far.
cons:
- No established/widely recognized union for TAs and RAs yet (but it's getting bigger I think). I don't know why there still isn't a union after so many years of existence of the uni, but I speculate that there must have been some headwinds from the uni to prevent that. Therefore the negotiation power of grad students on jobs is not much. (-1 star)

- Even though the uni has claimed that there are a lot of ways to gain support as a grad student & employee of the uni, I am very concerned about the way my department delivered the orientation on TAing. When addressing pay and workload, the words that were spoken and typed on slides included: 'be professional', 'do not complain about your workload heavier than other TAs', 'you don't have to be a TA and we don't have to fund you either', etc. I sincerely do not think this is the way you'd like to impress your new grad students. AND THIS ATTITUDE IS FAR FROM BEING PROFESSIONAL. (-1 star)

review_title: Was great, until they decided to mandate mRNA vaccination
pros: Good benefits, great people, opportunity to build a career by career pathing
cons:
UW is not taking the opportunity to allow people to continue to work from home, even for those who are thriving, are more productive or are simply wary of returning to campus mid-pandemic, whatever their stance on vaccination status. 
Their messaging around vaccinations during the pandemic has gone from, "no one's employment will hinge on vaccinations status" to "staff must declare their vaccination status" and will only "provide accommodations for rare cases", ultimately coercing their staff, students and faculty into submitting to an experimental medical treatment.
This is a matter of the right to decide what happens to your body, and this move is unprecedented in Canada. I no longer recognize the country that I was born in and have lived all my life.

review_title: Enjoyability depends heavily on coworkers. If they pull their weight and you yours, you'll have  a fine time.
pros: Cheap meals included along with free coffee while on shift (I worked the ML Tim Horton's); work was steady and relatively even, once I got used to the required hustle.
cons: The enjoyability of the position, as I mentioned, lies heavily with your co-workers. My primary co-worker, a long-time full-timer named Kathy, was an absolute treat to work with - she trained me beautifully and ran me just as much slack as I deserved while never failing to reprimand me when I screwed up. However, if your partner is unwilling to work as hard as you are, it can build resentment - as it can if you're the one not doing your share. Even if you're both willing to pull your own weight, if you've got no rapport with your partner it can lead to silent, stressful shifts, so being able to get on with your coworkers is a must.

pros: If you are looking for a steady job with a pension and reasonable hours, this is the place for you. 9-5 mindset and overall there is flexibility with your hours as well. Great place for managers and highly recommended for individuals with families. Contrary to other reviews I've seen, the salary is fairly decent.
cons: Overall, this is not a great environment for younger professionals and there will be very little room for growth within the organization. The academic support staff is fairly uneducated and very close-minded, especially on the management level. Definitely not "Canada's most innovative university" in terms of its operations. Upper management makes many decisions without much consultation and does not respect the input of younger employees. "Ok boomer" definitely applies here and your age matters a lot (this organization seems to correlate age with experience and knowledge, which is not true in the real world). Extremely challenging to update/implement changes, staff are not recognized for their work, lot's a "dead weight", lack of direction, and riddled with outdated systems/process that are poorly integrated. Many of these issues stem from a lack of education and understanding.

review_title: Rich Research Community. Highly Credentialed Faculty. Experiences May Vary.
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Waterloo, ON
pros: Excellent researchers on staff. Tremendous resources available to grad students from compute time to undergraduate assistants. Very smart people all around. Great facilities.
cons: Faculty have total freedom in how they manage their grad students, meaning some are quite authoritarian. Mine wasn't, but other folks had nightmarish bosses who would force them to work crazy hours and overload them with side projects. Environment is very work focused, don't expect much socialising outside of work.

pros: As an undergraduate researcher, this is the first chance where you really get to exploring interesting problems. Coursework does not give the same sense of scale - it's an entirely different experience on your own research projects. You have to do whatever you can to solve it; there is no formulaic way, no "correct answer" waiting for you that you have to work your way towards. My advisors were extremely intelligent and helpful and gave me the freedom to pursue my own research interests while providing insightful advice at every step.
cons: The pay is obviously going to be a disaster but if you are not a big spender or can pull some research grants, it's livable. However this job probably isn't about the money

review_title: Lots of potential, but bloated and beauracratic at times.
pros: Lots of resources on campus for various aspects of your life.  The campus is fairly close-knit, so travelling from one facility to the other is not difficult.  The city of Waterloo is a relatively clean and safe place to live, with affordable housing and a relatively large number of things to do for a small town.
cons: Not as much funding for grad school as other universities, no all departments have all departments have good facilities, upper management can be prone over-work and/or low moral.  Not as technologically advanced as one might expect of the birthplace for RIM.

pros: If you get the right manager and job fit, it can be a great place to work. Nearly-free courses and okay benefits, as well as a pension.
cons: No vacation in your first year, partial vacation for your second year, three weeks of vacation starting in your third year. I almost didn't take the job because of this policy; sometimes I still wish I had kept looking. It's a long time to go without a decent break.  It takes several years to get a parking spot near your building, so calculate in extra travel time every day.

job_title: Food Service Worker in Waterloo, ON
pros: work in Campus, convenient transportation,  may change from diferrent brand of Food Service easily, no worry of job loss because University is one the most stable insititution, including all-can-eat meal
cons: low salary, because there are so many students would conpeting the positions considering the convenience from classroom to job.  Training class include AccessAblity Course, which is for the students and scholarships, talking about syllabus, time management etc. , something overly difficult and unnecessary to this positions

review_title: Excellent compensation if you work hard
pros: I completed my PhD in Computer Science at the University of Waterloo. I earned a NSERC Canada Graduate Scholarship (35,000) for 3 years. The University topped this up 10,000. CS also has an internal scholarship (Cheriton) which is another 10,000. Generally, if you can get NSERC (very competitive), you should be able to get a Cheriton (competitive) as well. Finally, the school allows you 3 TAs/year on top of this (or your advisor can buy you out): ~7000. The 55K is tax free and the 7K is taxed (but under the basic exemption amount), so it is equivalent to a mid-70K taxed job.
cons: A lot has been written about the drawbacks of doing a PhD. I am not addressing these. If you have already chosen to do one, then consider Waterloo.

job_title: Software Engineer Undergraduate in Waterloo, ON
pros: Co-op is a big plus. Employers include Google, Microsoft, IBM, Pinterest, Facebook among many other less-know companies.  The studies are challenging and require time and dedication.
cons: There is less time for self-learning technologies and a lot of stuff that we are taught in first and second year includes topics like Kinematics, Chemistry, Linear Circuits which might are usually not directly useful or related to software engineering. These are bare minimum subjects to call "software engineering" an "engineering degree. Thus, time is consumed learning things which are not needed for jobs.

review_title: A fun and relaxing workplace atmosphere
job_title: HRMS Project Assistant in Waterloo, ON
pros:
Working for the University has its pros. The workplace atmosphere is very relaxed and the people you work with are awesome. 

Since you are already here at the University you have the opportunity to take classes (if your employer agrees) and other development courses in leadership etc.
cons: The University pays their students based on their own salary's depending on faculty and year. It is not bad pay but I believe you would get paid more working for a company outside the university.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Waterloo, ON
pros: Calm environment with relatively good payment. If you get good grades you can earn more with financial awards. You can do teaching assistantship too.
cons: Please Please don't do PhD with just any professors, you will be wasting your life for 5 years. Look at the alumni of the group you are going to join and see where they ended up being. There exists groups with certain ethnicities. For example, Chinese prof with all 20 chinese grad students, or Arabs or Persians or .....

review_title: My first job as a laboratory technician in a neuroscience lab
pros: I worked as a laboratory technician, supervising the daily lab activities, maintaining the equipment and the cell lines. This job allowed me to gain working experience while learning new techniques in a friendly and  supportive environment. Dr Spafford has a way of encouraging  and inspiring the members of his lab without putting unnecessary pressure on them. Working in the research can be frustrating and challenging at times but overall this was a rewarding experience
cons:
This it was a 6 month contruct and now I am on the market again, looking for something a little more long term.
The salary could be higher.

pros: My courses allow me to gain insights into how university and professional degree students think, work, and what motivates them. Seeing learning happen is also very motivating and rewarding!
cons: U of W is not eactly an MIT or Harvard or U of Toronto in that it is not super resource rich. However, this encourages innovation, something Waterloo is known for.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Waterloo, ON
pros: Institute for Quantum Computing at Waterloo is a great place for those researchers in quantum information and quantum computing fields. Every professor is an expert in their area, and most of them are very welcome to answer your questions. There are many different labs in the buildings. My advisor is really nice,  and he gave me many recommendations while I was applying to graduate schools in the US.
cons: My advisor was very busy, and he did not really have time to guide my research. Most of the time, I talked to the PhDs and Maters, which was fine but not great.

pros: Doing a PostDoc at University of Waterloo is generally good. It is a nice university with good academic environment for people who want to pursue a career in Academia. Small, quite city with everything you need.
cons: A bit too boring from time to time. You got to find something interesting to do besides your daily lab work. Don't work too hard and let the research consume your life.

pros:
University of Waterloo is one of the best universities in North America being constantly ranked first as the most innovative Canadian university.  
It has a huge campus and great facilities with most of the labs and classrooms being modern and well maintained.
You get to see people from all over the world getting together and enjoying undergrad life. Courses are demanding, time consuming and challenging, but you have the satisfaction of being part of a high end environment.

cons: My co-workers were rather difficult to work with. There were times when I enthusiastically bring up ideas or solutions and I was ignored.

pros: i live on campus. i like being a student because i can have summers off and im not in co-op so i don't have to work all the time.
